Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press their tongue with the instrument we mentioned earlier.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take the water I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and mix it with a non-extinguished lime, and make it neither too thick nor too subtle, and fill the concavity of this instrument, which is of this shape.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the extremities of it be where the medicine is placed, curved like the curve of a cochlear radius.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on the same ulcer: and let the patient be lying on his side, so that saliva flows out of his mouth from the inner medicine, so that nothing descends from it into his throat, and harms him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you apply it first to the ulcer in the quantity of a mid-hour dose, until you see it already darkened and soothed by the biting of the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to receive the pus, and wrap it around the extremity of the radius, and pour the pus with medicine, and insert the radius with the pus into a tube from above, until the pus adheres to the ulcer.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that many times, until you achieve what you want regarding the cauterization of this ulcer.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then dismiss her: for she will then take care of herself and will fall after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	What if you intend to administer medicine, administer it thus: and after cauterization, wipe away the area around the wound with a cloth soaked in butter, and cleanse it with what is around it from the medicine; and cool it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with poultices, and internally with gargles, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This therefore is a more wholesome method of treatment by incision and longer free from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when an ulcer is treated also with what is more subtle than cauterization and incision: it is treated indeed with fumigation, in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calendula, and hyssop, and origan, and rue, and ssea, and chamomile, and abrotan, and similar ones among the herbs: and gather all of them, or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar, and boil: and let the pot be well-coated with clay: and let there be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which an instrument concave according to this manner is placed.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or copper: and let the extremities be introduced, in which there is a pellet, into the mouth of the weak person, until the vapor ascends to the ulcer through a reed, until the ulcer is much obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat it many times over it, until it takes care of itself.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, lest you perform this treatment at the beginning of an apostemic disease.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For it is added in an aposteme: and it is not suitable to perform that unless at the decline of its warm aposteme.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If you do not have this instrument at hand, then take a reed, and place a layer of cortex on its extremity: so that the mouth of the weak person is not burned: because the cortex prevents the vapor from burning the mouth: and this is part of good treatment with health.
Â¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of spines and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times a bone sticks in the throat, or a fish bone, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore to extract what appears above what has fallen, after you have pressed the tongue with an instrument towards the roof of the mouth, and it will be clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary to make a weak vomiting before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps indeed the attached thing will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or swallow a weak piece of turnip, or the root of lettuce, or swallow a morsel of dry bread: or take a piece of dried marine sponge and tie it with a thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it reaches the place where the spines or bone are, and is extracted, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we have said: then use an instrument made of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius of a finger, and at its extremity let there be a curvature, which introduces itself into the throat with ease: and let it have its head elevated upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let it beware of touching its epiglottis, lest it should cause a cough, and the doctor pushes with his hand, either the bone or spine, or introduces it himself.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	However, what the doctor introduces gently is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the attached thing: and he pushes from below, or pulls with his hand and instrument upwards, all that according to the quantity prepared for him, until it comes out.
Â¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the extraction of leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I said earlier in the section on cures with medicines, and it does not work, then consider the throat of the weak patient in front of the sun, or towards the sun after you have pressed his tongue with an instrument as I described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your vision falls upon the blood vessel, extract it with a small hook or with delicate fingers from below.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	What if it is not possible with these: then take a concave cannula, and insert it into the throat of the injured person up to the throat: then insert the iron rod heated with fire into the concavity of the cannula.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that many times: and let the injured person abstain from water for a whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full treatment of cold water, and open his mouth in it: and let him wash his mouth with it, and not swallow anything from it: and move the water one hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the blood vessel falls out when it feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not come out with what we have narrated, then fumigate the injured person with bug-losses, or with a bean-like instrument which I described in the fumigation of the ulcer.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that many times, until it falls out.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is, that you take a pot, in which there are burning prunes with fire: and the pot is covered with a lid, in the middle of which there is an opening: and the extremity of the instrument is arranged in that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then apply the fumigation, and let the injured person put his mouth at the extremity of the cannula, and close his mouth, so that the fumigation does not escape, until he knows that the fumigation has already reached the blood vessel.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the blood vessel will immediately fall out.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall out, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the injured person endure hunger, and eat salty things, and garlic, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that it falls out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which a blood-sucking worm is extracted from the throat, when it falls upon it with force.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curvature which is introduced into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is similar to the beak of a bird called a stork, in which there is roughness of a file: when it grasps something, it does not release it at all.
Â¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of abscesses, and their section, and treatment in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many species of abscesses, of many modes, according to what comes to mind about them, namely one, and one in this book: and they differ in their perforation and sectioning, which is from two modes.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is of the species of abscesses in itself, and that which it comprehends from humidity.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is due to locations, in which it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess occurring in the head is different from an abscess occurring in the anus: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place is different from an abscess occurring in a joint: and each of them has its own judgment from the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And among the abscesses there are those that should not be perforated unless after the maturation of the pus in them, and its completion: and among them there are those that should be perforated while they are raw, and do not mature according to their completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses which are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because when an abscess occurs near a joint and prolongs its being until it putrefies what is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint may be corrupted: which is the cause of a prior contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess near a principal member: because if you delay the perforation of it until it matures, it will harm either that member or through that principal member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	It is near the anus, so perforate it when it is immature: and it is not fitting to make a perforation, lest an unripe apostema should putrefy, unless it is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and it reaches to the interior of the intestine, and it becomes a fistula, or it becomes in its terminus which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is fitting to know the time of perforation of the apostema, which has matured according to its complement: and it is at the sedation of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness, and pulsation, and acuteness of the head of the apostema: and the remaining signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is fitting to make the perforation in the inferior place of the apostema, and of the more prominent elevation: and let the perforation be made in the length of the body, if the apostemata are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of the muscles, and tendons, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflexion.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those that are reflected, let the perforation be made with the membrane according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the apostema is in fleshy places: then it is better to delay its perforation until its digestion is confirmed, just as we said according to its complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there are many filths and foulnesses, and perhaps its lips become hardened, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some apostemata are perforated according to the width of the body in case of necessity: or according to that member which needs it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is fitting to administer a small perforation in small apostemata, and a large perforation in large apostemata: or many sections according to the similarity of the magnitude of the apostema.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are those among the apostemata, in which it is fitting to sew up the skin: and an incision should be made when it has already become like a pannus, and it has been made at the terminus, which has already died: just as that which happens in many cases, such as dubellae and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And of these are those which are cut with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And of these is one, from which an incision is made as the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like a groin abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And of these are those in which a round incision is administered, and a lunar incision; and similar ones from these incisions.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That one indeed which has no head, like superficial lenient abscesses, it is necessary to perforate them with a superficial perforation, or only with a flat one.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the abscess is large and has already collected a great deal of pus, and you perforate it, that you do not press too hard and extract all the pus at that time; rather extract from the same part itself.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply a poultice to the abscess until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do that many times according to the gradation, until it goes out: especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old decrepit person: for the animal spirit is often resolved with the egression of sanies: and perhaps the weak person will die, and you do not perceive.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore this chapter requires great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your perforation, by which you perforate the abscesses, it is necessary to clean the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound of the abscess is small, or it is a flat section, then administer a dressing made of linen, or an old cloth.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if it is a large abscess, and there are many perforations with fissures, then it is necessary to introduce a dressing into every fissure, until they reach the adjoining skin.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut away a part of the skin in the abscess, or concavely hollowed it out around it: then it is necessary to fill it with an old cloth, or as when a fabric is woven, or padded with a layer of linen without moisture: and bind it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then apply it, and take care of that with what is suitable from the ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if a flow of blood occurs during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after it has been soaked in those rags; and apply it many times to the place of the flow of blood.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood persists, then it is necessary to administer a regimen and treatment, and powders, which I described in many places of this our book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in winter time, and the place of the apostema is of many nerves: then it is necessary to soak poultices with wine, and warm oil; and apply them to the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer, and the places are fleshy: then it is necessary to apply poultices soaked in water, and oil, or with wine and oil, and all that is cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until when it will be the third day, as we said, then it is necessary to dissolve the apostema, and wipe it away, and administer in its treatment what is suitable for it, until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the knowledge of treating apostema universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the path of distinction, I have already spoken about every apostema, and how it is a way to its treatment, chapter by chapter, individually.
Â¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Of the apostema that occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Head 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	There occur on the skin of the head small apostema, and they are from the species of Knots, which are contained in tunics, which are like sacs: as if they were hollowed out by a hen's beak.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many species of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some of them are fatty; and some contain moisture similar to slime; and some contain moisture similar to frost and pus; and those similar, and some are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the cutting of all and their extraction, there is no fear, as long as the artery does not make a contradictory incision at the site of the cut.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their cutting is such that you should experience it with an instrument, whose form is presented afterwards, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if there is that which contains moisture, then dry it with a sectional incision along the length of the superficial section: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the incision from line b to line g. When therefore the moisture is evacuated, then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture, and do not allow anything to penetrate deeply from it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it often returns, if something remains from it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then soak the wound in Egyptian unguent, if it is available: and if not, in water and salt: and fill with it a dressing, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it corrodes what remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then apply the Egyptian unguent to the wound a second and third time, and if you are uneasy about it, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then treat the wound with an ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	What if the aposteme contains a fatty node: then dry it according to this form, with an incision having the shape of a cross: and insert a hook between the two labia of the incision, and scrape it out from every part: and strive to extract the tunics that contain it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, the artery makes a contradictory incision for you, then do what I will tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly, act on the aposteme if it is stony, from the incision and the same treatment, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision above the stony aposteme is easier: because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain abscesses that are on the head in certain men, with which there is no deep humidity.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	This is because I cut above an abscess on the head of a little old woman, and I found the abscess to be like a hard and solid stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if someone were to strike it with a projecting point, they would wound themselves.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses occurring on the head, apart from these, namely those abscesses that occur on the heads of children and at the roots of the ears, the section of all of them should be a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make a perforation of them always from the lower part of them, so that the flow of sanies may be directed towards the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat them with what is suitable for them according to their treatment.
Â¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Of the section of Scrofulous swellings on the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur on the neck, and under the arm-pits, and in the groin areas: and sometimes they occur in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above those which occur on the neck, there are one and many: and they are produced by a humour: and every Scrofula arising from them is under its own tunic, just as it is in knots and abscesses of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these Scrofulous swellings.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And among them there are stony ones: and among them there are those that contain humidity: and among them there are malignant ones, which do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, in those that you find to be of good disposition on palpation, whose manifest colour is close to the colour of the skin, and moves towards every part, and is not attached to the nerves of the neck, nor to the glands, nor to the arteries, nor is it deep: it is necessary to separate it by a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body in a line, b. to a line, g., and to excise it from every part: and extend the two lips of the skin with a hook, or with many hooks, if you need it, just as we said in the case of abscesses on the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is above the caution, so that a vein or nerve is not injured.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the instrument be not sharp-pointed, so that it does not add to your hand with an incision, or disturb the weak part, and cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you have cut a vein, or an artery, or it prevents you from operating, then apply to the wound some crushed garlic, or certain powders that staunch blood, and bind the wound, and leave it until the acute pain subsides, and the wound softens: or it begins to suppurate.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is staunched by the tunic of Redi, therefore return to your operation, until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then probe with your index finger, if anything remains from the small Strophuli: therefore cut them, and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	What if there is a large vein in the root of the Strophula: then it is necessary that you do not cut that Strophula at its root: rather it is necessary to tie it with a double thread, and leave it until it falls off by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton, which you had already soaked in Egyptian unguent.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then treat it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire Strophula is cut, then it is necessary to bring together the two lips of the wound: and adjust them immediately, after you see that there remains no excess.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there remains an excess because of the size of the Strophula, then it is necessary to proceed to cut its root, and extract it: and administer the suture as we have said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what contains moisture from the Strophuli, pierce it with a superficial piercing: so that you see the place of its maturity: and put the piercing below the following part of the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer a linctus with ointment, and similar things, so that it corrodes what remains from the corruption, until you see the wound is now clean: then treat it with a generating ointment of flesh, until it heals.
Â¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	About the section of the epiglottis affected by an abscess that occurs within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients spoke of this section of the epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has performed it: and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	However, in those having a severe cough, it is necessary to avoid the section of the epiglottis: since no benefit is made through that: because all the veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those indeed who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or tonsils, when there is no disease in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the epiglottis, to flee from the destruction which is made by suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore it is necessary when we want to do that, to cut the epiglottis under three or four circular folds of the epiglottis, making a small section in width, in what is between two circles in quantity, so that the section is in the sifa, not in the cartilage: and this place is suitable for the section, because it is deprived of flesh, and the vessels of blood are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the doctor is timid, then it is necessary to stretch the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should probe the skin until he reaches the canal: he should avoid the blood vessels, if he sees anything from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he should cut the sifa which we have described: and it is marked above the section of the canal by the phlegm that comes out of it, with what is disrupted, and the separation of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for a certain period of time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour arrives at which the prefabrication is feared, bring together the two lips of the wound's skin, and sew it up itself without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medications that promote the growth of flesh, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Said Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this sermon which we have narrated is not an exposition, unless when they see that some of these apostemes had already putrefied in the throat of the infirm: and the infirm was elevated above death, and wished to intercept his breath; they wanted to dissect the Epiglottis, so that the infirm might breathe over the place of the wound with a certain respiration, and be saved from death: and for this reason they ordered to leave the wound open, until the evil of the disease was consumed, and it was an evil of three days, and almost itself; then therefore they ordered to sew up the wound, and to cure it, until it was healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw through myself is, that a certain maid grasped a knife, and sent it into her throat, and struck with it a part of the pulmonary canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to her cure, and I found her groaning, as is the groaning of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I examined therefore the wound, and I found blood which had flowed out from the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was confused therefore, because she had not severed a vein, nor an artery: and air was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I treated it therefore, and sewed up the wound, and cured it, until it was healthy: and nothing happened to the maid, except hoarseness in her voice: and she returned after days to a better disposition of hers.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore I say: that in the incision of the Epiglottis there is no fear.
Â¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the surgical incision of the hernia in the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess is called a hernia of the throat, it is a large abscess, according to the color of the body, and it is common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural one, certainly there is no ingenuity.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental one is indeed according to two modes: of which one is similar to fatty knots.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode is similar to an abscess that occurs from the thickening of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear in it, and it is not fitting to make a incision into it with an iron instrument, unless it is small; and you should test it, and examine it with a probe.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it similar to a fatty knot, and it is not swollen with any veins: then cut it off, just as knots are cut off: and extract it with what it contains from the sac, if it is in a sac: and if not, then probe the entire area.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the area with what is necessary for healing, until it is healthy.
Â¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the surgical incision of various kinds of knots.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already described all their kinds in the division: and it is necessary to relate here the difference between a Knot and an Exitus, since there is a doubt that causes confusion.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that since an Exitus is characterized by heat, and fever, and vehement pains, until the boiling of the surplus is suppressed, and the putrefaction is completed: then indeed the fever and heat cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But with a Knot, there is no heat, nor fever, nor pains, and it contains those sacs of sifachin, which are their own proper sacs, and they are according to the color of the body: and they are taken in like a seed, and become like a bubble, and they are greater and lesser.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds according to whether they are fat or contain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, according as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary, therefore, when you come to the cure of a Node, that you should try it and examine it first with an instrument which is called Intruded, according as its form will be described in the chapter which is after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining abscesses and all nodes is that you should take this instrument and insert it into a moist place which you find in the abscess: and you should slowly rotate your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has already penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then you should finally put your hand according to the measurement of the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then extract the Intruded instrument, and consider that which comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore a flowing moisture comes out, whatever the color may be: then dry it with a superficial incision, according as I said about the remaining abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if a moisture does not come out in the track of the Intruded instrument, then know that it is fat: therefore dry over it with an incision having the form of a cross, according to this form, as I taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and excoriate the skin from every part with ease: and keep it still if you can over it, so that you may extract the healthy tissue with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the stillness is disrupted during the operation, and it is not possible to extract the healthy tissue, for this often happens, then extract it fragment by fragment, until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little or much of it remains, the Node returns according to its fullness.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it defeats you and a little of it remains: then fill the wound at its completion with certain corrosive powders: and bind the wound, and put above it what sits as a warm abscess, and treat it with remaining cures, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore there is a large knot, then sew up its two lips, and cure it with that which makes flesh.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however there is a pulsating vein opposite you, or not pulsating: then prepare, and fill the place of the wound with a triple dressing, and leave it tightly bound for two days, or three, until the wound putrefies, and the ebullition of blood ceases: then return to cut open what remains of the Node.
Â¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning the forms of instruments for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of Instruments for Introduction, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For there is a large one among them, and there is a medium one among them, and there is a small one among them.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They are made from iron, with a square, quadrated extremity, so that they may firmly enter into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Probing Instruments, and yes, that is, piercing ones: and one of them is called a needle, that is, a perforator: and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For there is a large one among them, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating through these abscesses, and ulcers, and fistulas, and buboes from that which is among them, from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, slender, like large needles to which handles are attached, namely from citrine, or from copper, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better ones among them are those that are made from citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are made from black lead, which are suitable for probing fistulas, the concavities of which are reflections, so that they may reflect with their own gentleness along with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Since there are long ones among them, medium ones, and short ones, according to the quantity of the amplitude of the fistula and its constriction.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The forms of wounds, and they are of many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because some of them are simple, namely those with a single curvature, and they are of three species, as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And some of them are jagged wounds, and they are of three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And some of them are wounds having two curvatures, and they are of three species; and some of them are wounds having three curvatures, and they are of three species; and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which they cut and scrape away nodes and abscesses; and they are of three species: because some of them is large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which the section is made are sharp, other extremities are not sharp; and they are not placed thus, unless so that there may be relief in scraping away nodes with fear of incision into the vein or nerve; and so that the weak part may be healed through them, and may find tranquility for a while from the inflammation it finds at the scraping away of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are forceps, and they are of three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of copper, and they are similar to a file, with which an abscess is opened; and on the broad extremity there is a hidden pointed spatula: and it runs inward and outward when desired, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The forms of spatulas that are hidden between the fingers at the perforation of an abscess; and they do not perceive them as weak; and they are of three species, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of bleeders with which the flow of blood is stopped; and they are of three species, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of copper or brass, round, slightly longer, as you see; and they should be to subtlety.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these species of blood-letting be great and small with you, so that you may quickly draw out the blood through them in case of necessity, and then when no medicine is present to help you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you should not use them in blood-letting at every location on the body, and you should only use them at fleshy places: such as the veins of the legs, and hips, and the veins of the arms, and breasts, and abdomen, and groin, and similar fleshy places.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they are made from these small instruments similar to those of the fisticulers, according to their own shape: with which blood is drawn out when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or artery: and when they are made round according to this shape.
Â¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the treatment of men's breasts which resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men become swollen at the time of deep sleep (that is, when they begin to be polluted in their dreams) until they resemble those of women; and they remain disgusting and loathsome.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever therefore abhors that, it is necessary to make an incision above the breasts in a lunar shape, according to this form from line to line, b. to line, g. Then scrape out all the fatty tissue.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill in with a medicinal poultice of flesh incrustation.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and treat it, until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the breast declines to the lower parts and becomes soft due to its size, as happens with women: then it is necessary to make two sections on either side in a lunar shape, each of which is connected with the other at their edges, so that one line contains the smaller, according to this form from line to line, b. to line, g. Then scrape out the skin that is between the two lips, and remove the fatty tissue, and apply what we have said about sutures and poultices, which is necessary for healing, until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If you do not make a complete incision of what needs to be cut, because of the patient's anxiety or because of the flow of blood, then it is necessary to fill in the wound with a corrosive unguent and leave it, until it corrodes away what remains from the pus.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it, until it heals.
Â¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Concerning the perforation of a posternel, which occurs under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These posternels that occur under the nipple are of the species of hard Strophuli, which contain cysts, and among them are those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Those therefore that are among them which contain moisture, it is necessary to section them in a lunar fashion, according to this form, from line b to line g, so that everything that is in the posternel may be evacuated from the blood, then fill it with old cotton, and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the cotton is removed, and it is treated with a suitable ointment for that, until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the posternel was of the species of nodular Strophuli, then split it open above, as we have said in the section on Strophuli, equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, the wound extends to this point so that it emits pus, then apply a cautery to it, according to what we have said in the preceding matter.
Â¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the section of the posternel that occurs due to the Artery and Vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the Artery is ruptured and the skin that is above it is consolidated, then often an apostem (abscess) occurs there; and similarly it happens with the Veins as well, so that an abscess and inflammation occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that the abscess and inflammation are due to the Artery and Vein are: because when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long, aggregated deep in the body; and when you press on the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a stridor.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of the Veins, is round in the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section above this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and in the groin, and in the neck, and in many places of the body: and it is a great wound indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that his treatment should be undertaken with iron, and what is from them is also in the extremities or in the head, it is necessary that he should be treated.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Above therefore what is from them is from the inflammation of the arterial orifice, find in a gentle section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, afterwards the artery: and free it from its coats, until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce the needle under it, and make it penetrate until it reaches the other side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place which is between the two ligaments with a spatula, until all the blood that is in it flows out, and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a treatment that generates pus, until the ligaments fall off: afterwards treat it with suitable ointments, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	What if there is an abscess because of the section of a Vein, then it is necessary that you hold with your hand what you can from the abscess with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a needle under the place which you held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and let there be a double thread in it, until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie with the same abscess a good ligature: according to what I said to you about the ligature of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however the time comes that the thread is extracted, then introduce another needle with another thread under the entire abscess at the incision of the instrument: press, and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then, dissect the aposteme in its middle, until when it goes out what is in it; then, incise the superficies of the skin, and dismiss what is bound to it from that.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then, put on top of it a poultice which you have submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then, administer treatment, which is done with bandages and ointments, until it heals.
Â¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Concerning the aposteme that occurs due to twisting of the tendons.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an aposteme occurs in the Artery and Vein, similarly an aposteme occurs in the Nerves; which occurs from percussion, or occurs from excessive labor, and similar things; and it happens most often to them in the places of joints, or ankle, and in every place where the joints are moved; and it is a grave aposteme.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to that of the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain; and when it is constricted with violence, it feels in it a weakness similar to numbness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an aggregated aposteme deep in the body, but rather it is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not proceed to the front, nor forward, nor backward to the rear.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, since it is in the joints, it is not necessary that it be touched with an iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps a contraction occurs.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that case, since it is in the head or in the forehead, make an incision with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small aposteme, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off at the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and excavate it; then lift it out, and bring the wound together with a suture; and treat it, until it heals.
Â¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the excision of an aposteme that occurs in the belly.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It happens to certain men that many times there are growths in their intestines and in other parts of their bodies, which are called Fungalia, because of their similarity to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is subtle, and their head is large, and their lips are turned inward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is small among them: and it is among them what is greatly esteemed.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I have seen a man, and in his belly there were two growths, which were more similar to mushrooms than anything else: there was no difference between them, white, with small roots, and their lips turned inward, and they were covered over, and moisture flowed out of them always.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut into them, and I found that one weighed almost 10 ounces and the other almost 8 ounces. And the operation of cutting into them is, as you consider then, if the patient is humid, and the color of the growth is white, humid, with a subtle root: then cut into it with a broad spatula, and let your cauterium be present in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often a lot of blood is expelled during the dissection of it: therefore, if you are overcome by the bleeding, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the patient is pale and timid after the incision with iron, then take a thread made from lead, well-fashioned, and tie it around the vessel: this is the method I mentioned, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the stricture of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease to tie the lead, as often as it is impressed on the growth, until it is cut off, and it falls away by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the growth is large-rooted, then there is something to fear and be anxious about in its incision: especially because it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Truly, it is possible to cut into half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize him, so that he does not relapse.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat him, until the wound heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you suppose that a hard, fusiform, painless, foul-smelling tumor is anything but a cancerous aposteme; for I have seen it with the memory of Cancer after this.
Â¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of prominent umbilical hernias.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Umbilical hernias occur from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or they arise from cracks in the siphac, which is above the navel; and there emerges from it a gut or intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or they arise from blood that flows from the Vein, or from the Artery, according to what has been mentioned before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or they arise from a constricted flatulence in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is due to a crack in the siphac and an emergence of thronging: then it has a color similar to that of the body, and it is smooth, without pain; and it appears to be in different locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to an emergence of the intestine, then its location is with what we have described, of a more severe diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press it with your fingers, it is hidden; then it returns, and perhaps there is a noise with it; and it is greatly magnified upon entering the bath, and a severe labor.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If, indeed, it is due to moisture, it is smooth; then it does not hide when you press on it with your hand, nor does it contract, nor does it increase.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	What if it is due to blood, then with these signs it appears as an aposteme inclining towards blackness from the wound.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If, however, it is due to a born flesh: then it is a grave, thick, hard, and fixed aposteme, according to one quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to flatulence, then his touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, as you should consider then, if the prominence of the navel is due to blood of the Artery, or Vein, or flatulence: then it is necessary to refrain from its treatment.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and anxiety, as I instructed you in the chapter where I mentioned that abscesses are due to the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	Since the prominence of the navel is due to the intestine or a swelling: then it is necessary to prescribe for the patient, so that he may hold his breath, and stand upright, extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then apply signs with an cauterizing iron around the entire circumference of the navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards, instruct him to take a deep breath between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a broad spatula around the circumference of the navel over the place you signed with the cauterizing iron.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards, extend the middle of the abscess upwards with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it around strongly with a thread, or with a firm silk cordage: and let the knot of the ligament be hidden.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the abscess extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you have found it already caught by the ligament: then extract what is hidden, and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the belly: and if you find a swelling, then take it with the hook, and cut away its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the artery or vein is contrary to you: then surround it greatly.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two needles around the circumference which you made around the abscess in the shape of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then, the aposteme is strangled in four places above the wound; and if you wish, remove the wound, and abandon the place, until the rotten flesh extends and falls off by itself; or cut it open when it becomes subtle and rots.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then, treat it with what is suitable from ointments, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	What if the swelling of the navel is from fatty flesh in it, or from moisture; then it is necessary to concave the aposteme, as we have said.
