I then applied a sharp, corroding medicine to the wound for many days, until it opened up; and when I probed it, I felt the subtle tip of the arrowhead that was stuck in the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound through that sharp medicine, until the tip of the arrowhead appeared visibly to us; and it took me about four months with him to complete the treatment.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had grown larger, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move them around, but they did not obey for its removal: then I did not cease from cleverly thinking and contriving over it with various contrivances, until I managed to remove it on a certain day with skillfully made forceps, according to the shape of their tips described at the end of the chapter, so that I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed the physicians judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I then restored it, and the wound was consolidated, and he was completely healed with integral health; nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will teach you the method of extracting an arrowhead: so that you may apply a rule and indication on what I did not mention.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions are not understood with narration: nor does the book comprehend it, and the skilled artisan compares a little with much: and with what is present, about what is absent: and he discovers a new operation, and a new instrument through the descent into extraordinary things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrowheads do not come out from the limbs in which they are fixed, unless according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by counter-pressure of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or is a proceeding arrowhead in the fleshy place: and it is attracted, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	What if it does not obey at the exit from the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you let it alone for some days, until the flesh that is around it putrefies: and its attraction is alleviated, and its egress.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone, and does not obey you at the exit, then leave it alone for some days as well: and try it with attraction and motion every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	What if it does not obey you at the exit after days, then it is necessary that you perforate around the arrowhead in the bone on every side with a subtle drill, until the arrowheads are loosened.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If the arrowhead is fixed in a bone of the head, and has already passed into one ventricle of the brain, and certain accidents that I mentioned appear from the weakness: then refrain from attracting the arrowhead, and leave it alone, until its condition becomes equalized after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrowhead penetrates to the sifaÃ§, then the death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrowhead is not fixed, unless it only lodges in a bony part of the body and does not penetrate up to the sifaÃ§; and he remains weak for several days, and none of those accidents befall him: then his ingenuity is in attracting the arrowhead and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed strongly, and does not obey you in attracting it: then administer the trephine around the arrowhead, as I narrated to you; afterwards treat the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrowhead is already hidden in a place of the body, and it is concealed and hidden from sensation: then probe for it with a tent.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If, however, you feel it, then attract it with certain instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot reach it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrowhead in the depth; and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then enlarge upon it, until the wound is amplified, and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	Since there are anchors by which it is held, then liberate the fixed flesh from them on every side, with all the ingenuity you can, and strive, if you cannot overcome the evasion of the flesh in the fracture of the anchors, and their contortion, until it is freed.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you, when you administer the extraction of the arrowhead, in whatever place it is, then use the contortion of your hand, with forceps on all parts, until you make it come out: and be subtle with utmost subtlety, so that the arrowhead does not break, and its attraction becomes difficult for you, and even its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	Since if you cannot overcome it at one hour, then leave it for several days, until what is around it becomes putrid.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then you should approach it: for if the outer skin is injured, and if it causes a counter-flux of blood to you, then administer what we have said about treatment in its chapter: and preserve your strength from cutting into the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way that is possible for you to ease the tension of the bowstring: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have narrated to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary, that you do as you draw the bowstring, so that it may be weak according to its shape, according to what it was at the time of the case of the bowstring itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The bowstring which emerges from the opposite part of the other, or already proceeds from it to the exterior: or it makes a swelling of the extremities of the bowstring through sensation from the superior part of the adjacent skin, and you see it prominent: therefore cut above it, and let the section be according to the quantity that the forceps grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for it itself becomes easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the bowstring impresses on the bone, and it itself becomes larger: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for some days: then approach it again, until it emerges.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	What if the wood of the bowstring is in it, then push it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the wood has fallen out, and you want to administer an impulse: then introduce into it a concave instrument, so that its concavity enters into the tail of the bowstring: then push it out with the same.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow-head is concave, then push it out with an instrument inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow-head is extracted through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	What if the arrow-head is poisoned, then it is necessary to excavate the entire concave flesh where the poison is: if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	What if the arrow-head is lodged in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is close to what you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to dissect above it: then dissect, and be careful about the incision of the vein, or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the wound, if you see fit, and treat it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the method of forceps, with which arrow-heads are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are extremities similar to a bird's beak, which are made like scissors: when they grasp onto the arrow-head, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are made into many species, large, small, and medium, according to the quantity of the arrow-head's size, and its smallness, and the width of the wound, and its constrictions.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of a concave pusher.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of a straight pusher.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is a straight extremity like a rod, so that its point is extracted into the concave arrow-head, and it is pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremity of the concave pusher is concave like a bird's feather: so that the point of the arrow-head is extracted into it and its thrust.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of the bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 147.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins to be bloodletted, whose course is customary in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From which there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins, which are behind the ears, called two Herbae; and two arteries, which are apparent in the two temples; and two veins which are in the two lacrimal ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Jugular veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins that are cut for bloodletting in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it is from the Sylvester side; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Dark One.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branch of the Basilic vein and the branch of the Cephalic vein; and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein, and it is placed on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Vein of the Arm, and it is placed above the bend; and it is the one that is cut for bloodletting, and it is the one that appears above the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Salvatella; and it is a vein which is between the ring finger and the little finger; and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the vein that is under the curve of the thumb on the Sylvester side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its place is at the heel on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nesse: and its place is at the heel on the outer side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three similar veins.
Â¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Concerning the bleeding of two veins behind the Ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bleeding of two veins which are behind the Ears is a remedy for ancient catarrhs, and hemicrania, and saharfat, and evil old head sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the bleeding is according to what I narrate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is done by scraping the head of the sick person: and rubbing their occiput in the place of the two veins with a rough cloth, using good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the sick person should bind their neck with a cord, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of them are behind the Ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, feel for them with your finger, and where you sense the pulse of them beneath your finger, mark it there with a branding iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a lancet, and it is the one that is called an Incider.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein in the skin, until the lancet reaches the opening of the vein.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and make an incision in the vein with a cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or around that; and make it flow out of blood as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with soft cloths, and leave it, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now the cutting of the veins and their cauterization has preceded at the beginning of this book.
Â¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Concerning the bleeding of two Arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Here is the translation:
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding them is according to what I relate to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The string of the ailing neck is greatly affected, until two visible veins appear in a manifest sensation: and their pulse is demonstrated under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then, indeed, the signs are with a branding iron.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then, elevate the skin from above the vein upwards with your index finger, and insert the lancet obliquely beneath, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut into it, as you did in the two other veins: and make the blood flow out according to the quantity of your necessity.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then, release the constriction of the ailing part, and put your finger on the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, put a bandage over it and poultices, and bind it strongly above with a constriction: and leave it, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the description of those has preceded, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Concerning the bloodletting of the forehead vein after the bloodletting of the cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The benefit of bloodletting the forehead vein is after the bloodletting of the cephalic vein, for old facial weaknesses: and for hemigraine, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this bloodletting is according to what I relate to you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The ailing neck is constricted with a ligature, until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then, take the instrument which is called a Fossorium (lancet).
Cuius haec est forma.	Its form is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Put the sharp point which is on the head of the Fossorium (lancet) above the vein, and strike it with a plectrum, or with some other instrument in its manner: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity that you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the perforation of the wound and stitch it, until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens with a broad scalpel.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not suitable that the scalpel should be of a sharp extremity, like other scalpels, but rather of a broad extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the scalpels are divided according to the transverse cutting: because the bone is near: and perhaps the scalpel will be broken when it is subtle.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the venous scalping in two lacrimal veins.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal veins of the two eyes is for an eye affected by itchiness and redness: and a dirty condition in the eye, and facial weaknesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the scalping of them is such that it stitches the wounded neck with a thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the scalpel is thus: and you should stand above its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the scalping be done transversely along a short length, with a small scalpel, broad and somewhat flat, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the scalpel is of a subtle extremity, perhaps it will be broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make flow out from the blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a bandage over them, and stitch them up at night for one day, and dissolve them.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the venous scalping of the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The venous scalping of the Nose is beneficial for acute fever and violent headache, and facial weaknesses, such as half-headache and redness which occurs on the face: especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its scalping is that it stitches the wounded neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nose with your left hand, and take a subtle and long scalpel: and fix it in the middle of the nostril itself, between that which separates the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow suddenly.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is fitting that you should ultimately bleed your arm with a phlebotomy scalpel for a time; and you should make the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it with a bandage at night alone.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly indeed.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the Phlebotomy of Veins, by Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Indeed, Guidegi's phlebotomy is a remedy for constriction of the breath, and for leprous interception, and for melancholic ailments, and for evil ulcers, and corrosive sores, that is, herpes and other such things.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that it constricts the weak vein under both arteries in its neck with a bandage: and let the craftsman stand over the head of the weak person, and the weak person should sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then open the vein to the full length of the phlebotomy scalpel for a time.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to that which you see as necessary for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise regarding the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards, loosen the bandage, and constrict the two veins with a moderate stricture: so that the weak person is not suffocated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it stand until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will heal.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On the Phlebotomy of Veins, by Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Algeberich's phlebotomy of veins is a remedy: because it helps against inflammation of the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and evil ulcers: and cracks of the lips, and evil ulcers, even those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that you make the weak person sit in front of you: and constrict their neck with a cord.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn back the lip, and look at the two veins: one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the second is on its left; and their demonstration is through the dark bluish color.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because in the vicinity of those are small black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Make an incision on both sides, making a cut into each.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If you are in doubt and do not know which of them is, then make an incision on the larger one, and it will be more clearly manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do similarly for the two veins that are in the upper lip, and it is mostly customary to do so with them; and make an incision on the two veins that are in the lower lip.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Concerning the bloodletting of the Vein under the tongue, following the Cephalic bloodletting.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The benefit of the two Veins that are under the tongue in bloodletting is this: because the Cephalic bloodletting is for the purification of the things that are in the throat, and the cleansing of the ulcers, and the cleansing of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of performing bloodletting on them is such that the patient should sit between your hands in front of the sun, and elevate his tongue, and look under the tongue on one side for one vein, and on the other side for another vein: and their color will decline towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, perform bloodletting on both: and take care, lest you move your last hand while performing bloodletting on them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For underneath them are arteries, and perhaps a flow of blood may occur from those arteries.
Â¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Concerning the three Veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three Veins that are bloodletted in the elbow are those on which customary bloodletting is practiced in all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And the bloodletting of them is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a Myrtle-shaped lancet: or by draining to subtlety with an olive-shaped instrument: or by cutting with a scalpel-shaped lancet, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which is suitable for incision.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are broad and subtle species according to the width of the veins and their structure. The shape of the Myrtle-shaped lancet is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening concave veins, full ones, proceeding ones, apparent ones, thick ones, and those that contain thick, turbulent blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of smaller width and more subtle at the extremity.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bloodletting of subtle veins that contain thin, clear yellow blood.
Â¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On the bloodletting of Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilica, however, which is one of these three veins for bloodletting, is a benefit.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it extracts blood from the diseases that are beneath the throat and neck, since it follows the chest and stomach; and it is suitable for the bloodletter with this bloodletting, so that he may be cautious, and it is above fear because beneath it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he makes a mistake, and adds to the puncture of the bloodletter, he will cut that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Wherefore it is necessary not to bloodlet with a pricking lancet; rather, it should be cutting with an Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	Which if it does not appear in a clear and manifest appearance of Basilica, then it is necessary to transfer it elsewhere, and you will change it for another, or you will seek some other branch of it; or instead of the bloodletter, the rope of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For that is clear, and you will cut it with an Alnesil-shaped lancet, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you wish to perform phlebotomy on that same person, then it is necessary before constricting the arm, so that you may touch the place, until you recognize the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with a cautery, afterwards constrict the arm, and cut the vein at a curved section with a phlebotomy knife of Al-Nezal, as we have described.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And take care that the percussion does not fall through the space to the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that, as you constrict the ligament, an inflammation occurs in the place which you marked with a cautery, then that inflation is an arterial inflation: therefore beware of it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	What if you see the blood at the phlebotomy to be salty, like a child's urine, and it is subtle, red blood: then know that it is from an arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore press, and put your finger on the same long space, afterwards raise your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then constrict the arm, and release it: and beware lest the patient be weakened by its motion: and let it be above his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for some days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however the blood is not cut off, and it overcomes you: and there is no remedy present for you at that moment, then incise the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For the extremities are constricted, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a small linen cloth, and bind it: take one half, and constrict it over the place of the vein's constriction, with a ligature and soft padding until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then treat it with the method that preceded, remembering the place of the dust of the cut off blood flow: and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound location, and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
Â¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the bloodletting of the veins of the forehead.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the forehead bloodletting is beneficial, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and lower body; therefore, since it is composed of the basilic branch and the cephalic branch, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the bloodletter to open it, so that it may be above the terror from its bloodletting, for beneath it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore the bloodletter adds to the puncture of the bloodletting, and finds the nerve, there occurs in it numbness, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it does not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the senses.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in certain men, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then it is necessary that you place your bloodletting where you bloodlet, a section with the Alnesil, and divide the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	What if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
Â¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The bloodletting of the cephalic vein is beneficial, because it attracts blood from the head, and relieves the weaknesses of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein particularly, if you wish, to bloodlet it pricking with an olive-shaped bloodletter, or with a myrtle-shaped one: because it is the most healthful of all veins, since there is no artery beneath it, nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However it is fitting for you to bloodlet with caution, so that you divide the head of the vein only, and seek a smoother place: and it does not harm if it is not found with the first percussion, so that it may be repeated over it several times with bloodletting.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However perhaps there occurs an abscess in certain men when it is not bloodletted at the first percussion, but that abscess does not harm them in any way.
Â¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of bloodletting and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	However, the quality of bloodletting and its accidental effects resulting from it, which require careful consideration in its correct performance.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, it is essential to know that bloodletting should not be administered unless for the conservation of health, its preservation, and caution against the onset of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that bloodletting should be performed on one of the three veins that are located in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, the Fusca, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that bloodletting should be performed at the beginning of spring, on an empty stomach, and in the summer; and in autumn and winter after digestion, when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let bloodletting be performed on the first day, or on the third day, after three hours have passed since dawn.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, bloodletting that is administered for diseases does not have a fixed hour: but rather when convenience and necessity demand it, whether at night, or day, and in every hour, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not suitable for children to be bloodletted until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should pregnant women be bloodletted, unless from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old people be bloodletted who have already passed sixty years of age.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wishes to be bloodletted for any reason: it is necessary to cleanse their intestines beforehand with a gentle clyster, if there is much retained feces in them, so that the veins do not draw out putrid and noxious superfluities from the intestines during bloodletting, which harm the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should those who are tired or nauseous be bloodletted, nor those who are intoxicated from drinking, until they are freed from that condition.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And beware of phlebotomy repeated after a bout of passion, and vomiting, and flux of the stomach, and excessive coitus, and labor, and exercise, and wakefulness, and fasting, and all that which dissolves the virtues from the bodily or animal corpus.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors beforehand, if the blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him take a bath, if nothing prohibits it: or let him be exercised by some exercise, so that the blood may be subtly thinned.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And let phlebotomy be applied to his chest, around the third day, as we have said: and take care, so that his chest may be evacuated of all bad animal accidents on that day: such as anxiety, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and pain, and overexertion, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him have present things with which he is familiar through the use of aromatics, and perfumes, and trips and similar things to those in accordance with the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a pillow, which is higher than the pillow of the one being phlebotomized: afterwards let him draw out his arm, and rub it with his hand two or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tie the ligature with a cord, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the stricture be moderate, because when the stricture is unequal, or excessive in the stricture, then it prohibits the flow of blood: or in relaxation, then also it prohibits the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the stricture it is necessary to rub the hands of the one being phlebotomized simultaneously, until the veins become inflated and declare themselves to the senses.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the surgeon removes the bloodletting instrument with a little oil, properly and skillfully.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of his left hand on the vein under the location where he wants to perform the bloodletting, gently: so that the vein does not flee and is compressed by the percussion.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Since the vein is like a fleeing chord during bloodletting: and it is one of those that is full of windiness: and when you place the bloodletting instrument on it, it contracts under the instrument, and the surgeon is deceived, and the instrument does not open the vein: and if it opens it, it is constricted: therefore for this reason it is necessary to steady the instrument, and one should be solicitous in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he puts down the bloodletting instrument.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then the vein is opened with a single stroke, it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then try that stroke again at another place nearby with gentle pressure, or above it with quickness: if the spot is not missed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	What if the spot is missed, or the patient becomes weak, then leave him for a day, or two days: and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed it will attract a warm poultice.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should he take a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the bloodletting, if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	What if the opening is small, or the blood flows subtly: and sometimes so that the quantity of blood does not flow out as desired: then try the instrument again in the same opening according to the straightness, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it quickly, before the spot is missed, for a missed spot is frequent in many people during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it has already been missed, then do not try again at all, for nothing is exempt with regard to you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put upon it something from the dregs of oil: because it alleviates the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the dregs of oil in all your bloodletting, where the bloodletters prohibit the flow of blood: and they make that tyrical treatment, and sagzeneca, when it is applied from one of them to the affected area.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is subtly refined and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	When a large apostemation occurs at the site of bloodletting, which often happens, especially to one who has not been bled except at that time, or has a small opening of the vein, then apply and place on the area a sponge infused with hot water and salt for a short while: and bind it for an hour: because it is dissolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do that after the blood has flowed out of the vein itself, with a complementary treatment, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something blackish or greenish remains at the site after several days, it does not harm: and if you wish, apply to it something soluble of aloe, or myrrh; or something from the juice of menthastrum, that is, calament or similar to that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed, apostemations and swellings often occur at the site of bloodletting of the basilic vein.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand therefore upon it, then if you find softness at the site of your compression, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Take heed therefore, to apply to it something from what we have mentioned.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps the blood flows out of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make an application to it with that which has astringency, so that the site may be dried.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to extract from every man, in proportion to the quantity of his own blood, according to the amount of his vital strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the wine-like color above the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it becomes red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it flow out until it becomes subtle; and similarly if it is acute, until its acuteness is relieved.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs the extraction of blood once, that the phlebotomy of the veins be amplified, and the phlebotomist be skilled; and in him who is weak, let it be the opposite of this.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract it from the veins, and that the opening be narrow; and what is better administered in the phlebotomy of the veins is a crosswise section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from incision of a nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and more salutary than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to faint upon approaching phlebotomy, it is necessary that he eats beforehand a moderate bread infused in water of granated muzi: or dates, if he is overheated; and extracts from the blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if he is of an infrigidated complexion, then let him take beforehand bread infused in syrup of mia, or in syrup of honey aromatized with spices, or in syrup aromatized with fragrant odor.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	What if syncope occurs upon phlebotomy, and the cause of its abundant blood flow is multiple: then it is necessary that he takes in a drink water of flesh, and subtle fragrant syrup; and let him be treated with aromaticity with galangal, and his chest be lined with these; and let him use the remaining things which we mentioned in the division on syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wants to evacuate his arm and release his blood a second time: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is due to excessive evacuation, and his strength is weak, so that he releases the blood gradually according to his strength over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to evacuate his arm and release his blood a second time, and his body is strong: then he should do it seven hours later, or nine hours after his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to attract blood from his body to the opposite part to which it declines: it is necessary that he be evacuated on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whom there is already much heated blood in his body, and it becomes sharp, and causes a fever to occur: it is necessary that the blood flow out of him at once, and a large quantity be extracted from him; and the opening should be widened until syncopation occurs. After you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy, and you have placed your hand on his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not occur in place of syncopation.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens thus, when the phlebotomist is ignorant and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you want to release the arm and release the blood a second time, since the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, so that you press on it with vehemence, and the curvature is extended more quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a great evil, indeed abandon it, until it can be phlebotomized a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with an acute phlebotomy what has been coagulated from the blood in the opening of the vein, and apply to it something salty dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And apply to it something from tyriaca alfaroch or sagzenea, and apply a gentle compression, until the blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed an abscess has formed a vein, then leave it alone and do not touch it, until the abscess settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity provokes to release the blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either perform phlebotomy at that spot, or on another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are phlebotomized at the place of the Forked and Basilic veins, when they cannot be found, and are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that a weak hand is immersed in hot water, until it becomes red and the veins appear manifestly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let it be bound above it with a ligature of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the second phlebotomy transversely, gradually, not latitudinally, nor along the length; and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be such that you phlebotomize above the joint of the hand somewhat.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the flow of blood is prohibited, then immerse the hand in hot water, and let the blood flow into the water, until you achieve your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If however you are in the days of summer, then excuse yourself from immersing the hand in hot water repeatedly.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the flow of blood is mostly promoted by immersion in hot water during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is more beneficial than all the veins, because there is no pulsation beneath that vein, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the Salvatella vein on the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that you bind the hand with a ligature, or your own hand, after you have immersed it in hot water, until the vein becomes inflated and demonstrates its sensation strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then, he makes an incision across the vein.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm him at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful, lest you ultimately harm your hand with the scalpel.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For beneath it are the exposed nerve fibers of the fingers, stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put your hand into warm water, and let the blood flow from it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not soak it in warm water, the blood will clot in the opening of the vein, and be prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the necessary amount of blood, then apply oil and salt to the vein: so that it does not close too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly, it is necessary to do with every constricted branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The treatment of his phlebotomy from the left hand is this: because it is conducive to diseases of the spleen; and similarly do in his phlebotomy as you did in the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The treatment of the saphena phlebotomy is for diseases that are in the lower part of the body, such as diseases of the womb, and retention of menstruation, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar afflictions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that he should immerse his weak foot in warm water: and make friction upon it, until the veins overflow: and bind above the joint of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed the vein is located at the heel, appearing opposite the big toe: and many branches radiate from it on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Then make an incision on his larger vein, or at the heel in its confluence: because it is better and more healthy.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	For if you make an incision on the surface of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy there where you make incisions transversely, as if you were going to cut into it; and let the phlebotomist be skilled.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the flow of blood is prohibited, then put his foot in warm water, and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	What if the phlebotomist errs in the first instance, then let him repeat with phlebotomy above, for the place is sound, and you do not take evil from it when you cut into a vein, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel on the lateral side of the forest.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of his phlebotomy is to alleviate pain in the hip, when it is because of hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is that the weak patient should enter the bath, and be fastened: and let the leg be tied from the side of the hip up to the heel with a four-finger-long thin thread; for it does not appear otherwise except because of that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then make the phlebotomy according to whatever ingenuity is possible for you, or according to the transverse method: and it is better, either to cut into it with an incision, or to section it.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the location of it is more healthy, and it itself is hidden very deeply in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	What if you do not find it, and it does not appear to the sense at all: then make an incision on some branch of it, and it is that which appears on the back of the foot, and near the little ear: and cut into a vein, and let flow from the blood as much quantity as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the binding, and put a piece of leather over the place of the phlebotomy, and tie the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For a wound, indeed, it is healed.
Â¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Concerning the blowing, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 48.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventoses are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the blowing is done in two ways indeed.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bloodletting; and the other is blowing without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this blowing that is without scarification is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the blowings that are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the blowing of Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and the blowings of Alhagdahim, and they are two layers of the neck from both sides together; and the blowings of the mind, and it is under the jawbone in the lower jaw; and the blowings of the two spatulas; and the blowings of Alachosos above the end of the tail; and the blowings of the two thighs, and they are in the middle of the two arms; and the blowings of the two legs; and the blowings of the two hips.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the blowing does not extract blood from you through small scattered veins in the flesh, and because of that, virtue does not flow out from them, just as it is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to administer blowing, whether with fire or without fire, in any disease that occurs due to fullness, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	Because if necessity provokes blowing due to illness or because of habit, we administer it at every hour, at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	What is it, because it is from humans who, when the blood in them multiplies, then it needs to be extracted through venesection, finds a heaviness in its head and swooning.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there are those who find fullness and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there are those who find itchiness in their face, and forehead, and darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there are those who scratch the place of their venesection.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there are those who find a taste of blood in their mouth: or their tongue becomes blistered, and they spit out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see in their sleep blood and redness, and wounds, and sores, and things that are similar to them.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something of those, and it is specifically in the middle third of the month: we order then that venesection be done, after they have passed two days or three hours.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The benefit of venesection on the neck is that it reduces heaviness in the head and what flows out to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that it be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this indeed is instead of phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted that one should use it who has a cold complexion or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that it is not fitting that the old use it, and in whom there are cold headaches.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever, however, fits frequently over it, forgetfulness is generated over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of that it is fitting that you instruct the Venesectioner to put his hand with the venesection for a short time only on the lower parts, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The ventilation or Alkehel is the place of phlebotomy of Fuscae, and phlebotomy of Basilicae, and because of that it brings about constriction and narrowing of the windpipe, and fissure of the instrument of the windpipe, and coughing, and replenishment.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the Ventosa Alkehel is pressed strongly, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio indeed alhagdahim, brings about painful accidents in the head, and opthalmia, and hemicrania, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is the place of phlebotomy of Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you warn the Ventosator, not to press his hand with the scarification: so that he may not cut an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosatio however under the chin, brings about ulcers in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar things from the illnesses that are in the mouth: and it stands in place of phlebotomy of alieherich, which are in both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosatio however a spatula, brings about a treatment by friction, which is made from repetition and warmth.
